lines.text: But today, I've decided to take a risk, and wear a new sweater. It was sent to me by a recovering sex addict, Melissa D., who knitted it herself; she said it gave her something to do with her hands.
[Stuart is trying to calm his overweight sister Jodie on the phone]
Okay, Jodie, I would never ordinarily say this, but... is there any way you can get to a pound cake?
[Opening of Stuart's show "Daily Affirmations"]
I deserve good things, I am entitled to my share of happiness. I refuse to beat myself up. I am an attractive person. I am fun to be with.
I'm going to die homeless and penniless. I'm still twenty-five pounds overweight. No one will ever love me. I could just kill myself.
Stuart, that is just "stinkin' thinkin'."
[Stuart serves a patron in a restaurant]
Have you had enough time to look at the menu?
We've had enough time to memorize the menu.
I'm sorry, I'm having a personal crisis. Can I take your order?
For my wife, the Penne Arrabiata; and I will try the oso buoco.
You know, the oso buko is extremely fatty. You might want to try...
I'll TRY the oso buko. And also the mixed baby field greens.
Lo-cal vinaigrette?
Creamy Caesar.
On the side?
ON THE SALAD.
Thank you.
And I'd like another double-scotch.

[smiling]
No.
Oh, Julia, you don't know Roz. She's like a cootie, or something.
[Stuart reads a fan letter]
"Dear Stuart, your show gave me the courage to feel my feelings, and to feel my feelings about my feelings, and my feelings about my feelings about my feelings. And my..."
[Stuart skips ahead]
"God bless you, Amanda Q."

[narrating]
When the big night finally arrived, Dad had a new nickname for me.
Here we go. Is Sir Eat-A-Lot getting a little nervous?
Ha, ha, ha. "Sir Eat-A-Lot."

[narrating]
I was already nostalgic for "Waste of Space."
"I am a worthy human being."

[barely audible]
I am a worthy human being.
Okay, I really couldn't hear you. Try again.
I am a worthy human being?
No, Mia, it's not a question. Try it again.
I am... I'm sorry, what is the second part?
Worthy human being. I am a worth human being. Just say it.
I'm sorry, am I saying it to you, or to myself?
Just say it. I am a worthy human being.
I am a worthy human being.
Okay, louder.
I am a worthy human being.
Mean it.
I am a worthy human being.
Believe it.

[screams]
I HATE YOU, MOM.
[low]
Sorry.
you get me to lie, because if I don't, everyone goes to jail for perjury?
Because what they say is true - it's easier to put on slippers than to carpet the whole world.
If I do this, and it doesn't work, he's going to make my life hell.
How's your life now?
God, you'd drink too, if you had Liberace for a son.
When it comes to partying, no one gets down like people in recovery.
Trace it. Face it. And Erase it.
We'd all like to go home and save our families, but we can't. We're just not that powerful.
progress, not perfection.

[narrating]
My father grew up in the Great Depression - his mother's.

[despairing]
Listen to me. I'm should-ing all over myself.
Why don't you pick on somebody with pubic hair?
What?
You gonna give me the ball? Or would you like me to shove it up your ass?
[starts rolling up his sleeve]
Wanna hear my preference?
